title: Efficient Transformer Variants for Edge Deployment
bit: Transformer models are too large and slow for edge devices
flip: Develop compressed transformer variants using knowledge distillation and quantization
hypothesis: A 10x smaller transformer can maintain 95% of performance through careful distillation and 8-bit quantization
evaluationPlan:
1. Baseline: Measure BERT-base performance on GLUE benchmark
2. Apply knowledge distillation with temperature scaling
3. Implement 8-bit quantization with QAT
4. Measure: model size, inference latency, GLUE scores
5. Statistical tests: paired t-tests on each GLUE task
expectedOutcomes:
- Model size: 440MB → 44MB
- Inference time: 50ms → 5ms
- GLUE score: 82.5 → 78.4 (95% retention)
risksAndMitigation:
Risk: Catastrophic performance drop on specific tasks
Mitigation: Task-specific fine-tuning after compression
timeline: 4 weeks: 1 week setup, 2 weeks experiments, 1 week analysis

title: Physics-Informed ML for Iron Oxide Morphology Prediction
bit: Iron oxide morphology prediction requires extensive empirical knowledge and trial-and-error optimization
flip: Systematic ML with physics principles can predictively control morphological outcomes through thermodynamic and kinetic modeling
hypothesis: Physics-informed ML models incorporating Gibbs free energy, nucleation kinetics, and surface energy can achieve >85% morphology prediction accuracy and discover novel structures
evaluationPlan:
1. Collect comprehensive hydrothermal synthesis dataset (temperature, pH, time, concentration, surfactants)
2. Integrate physics features: thermodynamic calculations, kinetic parameters, surface energies
3. Train ensemble models (RF, XGBoost, NN) with empirical+physics features
4. Implement Bayesian optimization for active learning
5. Validate with cross-platform synthesis experiments
6. Statistical analysis: confusion matrices, SHAP interpretability
expectedOutcomes:
- >85% morphology classification accuracy (nanorods, cubes, spheres, flowers)
- Discovery of 2-3 novel morphologies through parameter space exploration
- Mechanistic insights into controlling factors via SHAP analysis
- Validated synthesis protocols for reproducible morphology control
risksAndMitigation:
Risk: Overfitting to training conditions → Cross-validation with different precursors
Risk: Limited parameter space coverage → Active learning boundary exploration
Risk: Physics model inaccuracy → Ensemble approach with empirical features
relatedWork: Liu et al. (2023) - ML iron oxide synthesis
Gu et al. (2024) - Deep learning nanocrystals
Nathanael et al. (2023) - Physics-informed microfluidic optimization
timeline: 8 weeks: 2 weeks data collection, 4 weeks model development, 2 weeks validation

title: Autonomous Multi-Property Optimization for Iron Oxide Nanostructures
bit: Traditional synthesis optimizes single properties sequentially, limiting multi-functional nanostructure development
flip: Simultaneous multi-property optimization through intelligent closed-loop synthesis control can discover optimal property combinations
hypothesis: Multi-objective Bayesian optimization can simultaneously optimize magnetic (SAR), optical, and catalytic properties with 3x efficiency improvement over sequential approaches
evaluationPlan:
1. Implement closed-loop microfluidic synthesis with real-time characterization
2. Deploy NSGA-II multi-objective optimization for competing objectives
3. Automated characterization: DLS, UV-Vis, magnetic susceptibility, catalytic activity
4. Pareto optimization for property trade-offs
5. Compare against sequential optimization baselines
6. Statistical validation: hypervolume indicators, convergence metrics
expectedOutcomes:
- Pareto-optimal solutions for magnetic/optical/catalytic properties
- 3x optimization efficiency vs sequential approaches
- Discovery of novel property combinations not achievable via single-property optimization
- Reproducibility <10% CV for all target properties
risksAndMitigation:
Risk: Equipment drift affecting measurements → Regular calibration protocols
Risk: Conflicting optimization objectives → Well-defined Pareto criteria
Risk: System integration complexity → Modular validation approach
relatedWork: Ortiz-Perez et al. (2024) - ML-guided high throughput optimization
Anker et al. (2025) - Autonomous nanoparticle synthesis
Portwin et al. (2025) - Surface state engineering
timeline: 12 weeks: 4 weeks platform setup, 6 weeks optimization runs, 2 weeks analysis

title: Real-Time Morphological Control with In-Situ ML
bit: Post-synthesis characterization limits ability to control morphology during formation
flip: Real-time morphological control during synthesis using in-situ ML can achieve dynamic parameter adjustment and optimal synthesis trajectories
hypothesis: In-situ SAXS coupled with real-time ML can identify morphology <5 minutes during synthesis and achieve 90% target morphology success rate
evaluationPlan:
1. Integrate in-situ SAXS with hydrothermal synthesis reactor
2. Deploy real-time ML for scattering pattern morphology classification
3. Implement feedback control for dynamic parameter adjustment (T, pH, precursor)
4. Use reinforcement learning for synthesis trajectory optimization
5. Compare real-time vs post-synthesis control performance
6. Validate with independent characterization (TEM, SEM)
expectedOutcomes:
- <5 minute real-time morphology identification during synthesis
- 90% success rate in achieving target morphologies
- Discovery of optimal synthesis trajectories for morphology control
- Reduced process variability (>50% CV improvement)
risksAndMitigation:
Risk: SAXS interference with synthesis → Dedicated flow-cell design
Risk: ML model latency → Edge computing optimization
Risk: Control system instability → Robust control algorithms with safety limits
relatedWork: Price et al. (2024) - Real-time RHEED-ML monitoring
Yoo et al. (2024) - Bayesian optimization for targeted synthesis
Papagiannis et al. (2021) - Systematic morphology control
timeline: 16 weeks: 6 weeks instrumentation setup, 8 weeks experiments, 2 weeks analysis

title: Cross-Synthesis Platform Knowledge Transfer
bit: Synthesis knowledge is platform-specific, limiting transferability between different synthesis methods
flip: Unified cross-platform synthesis intelligence can transfer knowledge between hydrothermal, microfluidic, and sol-gel methods
hypothesis: Domain adaptation neural networks can achieve >75% knowledge transfer efficiency between synthesis platforms, enabling universal parameter mapping
evaluationPlan:
1. Generate datasets from hydrothermal, microfluidic, sol-gel platforms with matched targets
2. Implement domain adaptation networks with adversarial training
3. Test transfer learning performance across platform pairs
4. Validate with novel platform (thermal decomposition)
5. Compare against platform-specific models
6. Measure data efficiency for new platform adoption
expectedOutcomes:
- >75% cross-platform prediction accuracy vs platform-specific models
- 50% reduction in experimental requirements for new platform adoption
- Universal synthesis parameter mapping framework
- Successful adaptation to thermal decomposition platform
risksAndMitigation:
Risk: Platform-specific physics limiting transfer → Include fundamental chemistry features
Risk: Limited transferability → Hierarchical transfer learning approach
Risk: Data distribution mismatch → Adversarial domain adaptation
relatedWork: Gu et al. (2024) - Cross-composition knowledge transfer
Liu et al. (2023) - Platform-specific iron oxide synthesis
Nathanael et al. (2023) - Generic microfluidic framework
